journal-meta.journal-title: Perspectives in Vascular Surgery and Endovascular Therapy

title-group.article-title: Pelvic Revascularization During Endovascular Aortic Aneurysm Repair

author-notes.corresp: Gustavo S. Oderich, MD, FACS, Mayo Clinic, Gonda Vascular Center, 200 First Street SW, Rochester, MN 55905, USA Email: oderich.gustavo@mayo.edu

abstract.p: Endovascular repair of aortic aneurysms (EVAR) has gained widespread acceptance in the treatment of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs). Prospective studies have shown advantages compared with open surgical repair, including decreased blood loss, operating time, hospital stay, morbidity, and mortality. Approximately 30% of patients treated by EVAR have ectatic or aneurysmal common iliac arteries not suitable for distal sealing zones. In these patients, one of the most commonly utilized options is exclusion of the internal iliac artery (IIA). Decreased pelvic perfusion carries the risk of ischemic complications, including buttock claudication, sexual dysfunction, and other devastating complications such as spinal cord injury, ischemic colitis, and gluteal muscle necrosis. This article summarizes the methods of pelvic revascularization in patients with aortoiliac aneurysms involving one or both common iliac arteries.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Endovascular repair of aortic aneurysms (EVAR) has gained widespread acceptance in the treatment of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs). Prospective studies have shown advantages compared with open surgical repair, including decreased blood loss, operating time, hospital stay, morbidity, and mortality. The long-term efficacy of EVAR is dependent on careful selection of patients with respect to anatomical factors. Although many of these anatomical constraints were previously considered to be relative contraindications to EVAR, technological advances have expanded the indications to include patients with more challenging anatomy.

Approximately 30% of patients treated by EVAR have ectatic or aneurysmal common iliac arteries not suitable for distal sealing zones.1,2 Common iliac artery (CIA) aneurysms affect 1 iliac artery in 43% of patients and both iliac arteries in 11%.1,3 One of the most commonly utilized options in these patients is unilateral or bilateral internal iliac artery (IIA) exclusion. Buttock claudication may occur in 16% to 50% of patients treated by unilateral embolization and up to 80% of those undergoing bilateral embolization.4-7 Sexual dysfunction is noted in 10% to 17%.4,5,8,9 Although uncommon, devastating complications include spinal cord injury, ischemic colitis, and gluteal muscle necrosis.10 In addition to the risk of pelvic ischemic complications, preservation of pelvic flow via the IIAs has been shown to be a significant collateral network to the spinal cord, reducing rates of spinal cord injury in patients with extensive thoracic or thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysms.11-13 This article summarizes techniques of pelvic flow preservation during EVAR.

sec.title: Flared Iliac Stent Grafts
sec.p: “Bell-bottom” or flared iliac stent grafts are one of the most commonly used methods to preserve pelvic flow in patients with small CIA aneurysms (Figure 1). The largest acceptable iliac diameter has recently increased from 21 to 25 mm with the addition of 27-mm flared limbs, but the technique can also be done with off-label use of aortic extension cuffs, permitting treatment of larger common iliac aneurysms. Ideally, the CIA should not be affected by thrombus or excessive calcification. Although the use of bell-bottom grafts simplifies the repair, the durability of this procedure remains questionable, with few clinical reports demonstrating long-term data.

caption.p: Flared or “bell-bottom” iliac stent graft limbs are used for ectatic or aneurysmal common iliac arteries

sec.p: Lawrence-Brown and colleagues from Western Australia reported that iliac arteries between 16 and 22 mm in diameter can be treated with 90% efficacy using “bell-bottom” grafts.14 However, after a mean follow-up of 30 months, endoleaks were noted in 40% of patients, including type-Ib endoleaks in 7%. Secondary reinterventions for iliac artery–related problems were needed in 10% of the patients. Torsello and colleagues15 reported type-Ib endoleaks in 3.4% of 89 patients treated with flared limbs, with 92% freedom from secondary interventions in 5 years. Other investigators have demonstrated that the rate of distal endoleaks or secondary interventions is low with flared limbs used according to the information for use in patients with adequate landing zone in the CIAs.16,17 However, a recent report by the Mayo Clinic group showed that the off-label use of flared iliac limbs is potentially associated with higher rates of complications. In that report of 71 patients treated with 93 limbs, continued iliac artery enlargement was noted in 86% of the patients, with the rate of iliac limb events being 17%, including sac growth >5 mm, type-Ib endoleak, and reintervention for retrograde limb migration.18

sec.title: Hybrid Revascularization
sec.p: Open surgical revascularization of the IIA can be performed using a retroperitoneal approach with a small curvilinear flank incision (Figure 2). Since its first description in 1999 by Parodi and Ferreira,19 hybrid revascularization of the IIA has been widely adopted as an alternative to coil embolization. The technique is also useful in patients with small iliac artery diameters who require iliac artery conduit.20

caption.p: Hybrid revascularization is performed using transposition or bypass from the distal external iliac artery to the internal iliac artery. The computed tomography angiography shows a patient with bilateral common iliac artery aneurysms treated by right iliac artery bypass and left iliac branched stent graft

sec.p: IIA bypass or transposition demonstrates excellent patency, ranging from 80% to 100%.6,19 Faries et al21 have shown 100% technical success and graft patency with no symptoms of ischemic complications of the colon, gluteal claudication, or sexual dysfunction in 10 patients. Similar results were reported by Arko et al22 and Lee et al6 when they compared open surgical IIA preservation with coil embolization. Both studies demonstrated significant decrease in buttock claudication and improvement in ambulation.23 Nonetheless, IIA bypass or transposition may be technically challenging and time-consuming, especially in obese patients and in those who had prior pelvic operations or radiation.

sec.title: Endovascular Revascularization
sec.p: One of the basic tenets of vascular reconstruction is to preserve normal anatomy and end-organ flow whenever possible. Innovative methods have been reported to preserve IIA flow in patients with aortoiliac aneurysms using total endovascular techniques. Iliac branch devices (IBDs) designed to preserve flow into the IIA have been shown to be clinically effective and safe. However, access to these devices is still limited, and long-term follow up is needed to determine branch patency and rates of iliac-related secondary interventions. Total endovascular techniques utilized to preserve iliac flow are described below.

sec.title: External to IIA Stenting
sec.p: External to IIA stenting was described by Bergamini et al24 and used successfully by Woo et al.25 The original description included aneurysm exclusion with an aorto-uni-iliac stent graft and lower-extremity revascularization by femoral crossover graft. Exclusion of the CIA is done by placement of Fluency (Bard, Covington, GA) or Viabahn stent grafts (WL Gore, Flagstaff AZ), which often require reinforcement by a self-expandable stent to prevent kink (Figure 3A). A modification of the technique described by Delle and associates uses an IIA stent deployed into one of the iliac docking limbs of the bifurcated graft (Figure 3B). Although these techniques avoid the need for retroperitoneal iliac artery exposure, the external to IIA stent is subjected to excessive tortuosity and kinking, potentially predisposing to late occlusion or narrowing. Another limitation is the need for extra-anatomical open surgical reconstruction of the femoral arteries, which is potentially associated with decreased patency and risk of graft infection.

caption.p: Treatment of bilateral common iliac artery stump aneurysms with external-to-internal iliac artery stent grafts (A). The computed tomography angiography demonstrates a patient with bilateral external to internal iliac artery stents (right occluded). An alternative option is placement of a stent graft from the docking limb of the bifurcated device to the internal iliac artery (B). A femoral crossover bypass is used to revascularize the contralateral extremity

sec.title: “Sandwich” or Parallel Stent Grafts
sec.p: The “sandwich” technique was first reported by Lobato26 using parallel stent grafts to preserve flow into one or both internal iliac arteries. A transbrachial approach is required for placement of a covered stent from one or both docking limbs of a bifurcated aortic stent graft into the IIA while a parallel stent graft maintains flow into the external iliac artery (Figure 4). Lobato advocates an overlap of at least 5 cm between the IIA and the external iliac stents to minimize risk of endoleak within the gutters of both stents.26 Limitations of this technique include the need to use longer internal iliac stents as compared with branched devices, the potential for compression of one of the parallel grafts, and lack of long-term controlled data on limb occlusion and endoleaks. Lobato and Camacho-Lobato27 have recently reported their personal experience, with excellent patency of 93% and only 1 type-III endoleak after a mean follow-up of 15 months. Despite these considerations, the technique has been endorsed by several centers with low rates of limb occlusion and endoleaks in early follow-up.28-30

caption.p: “Sandwich” technique using parallel stent grafts: the inset demonstrates the possible endoleak originating from the gutters

sec.title: Double Bifurcated Stent Graft or Trifurcated Stent Graft
sec.p: This technique described by David Minion uses 2 Gore Excluder stent grafts (WL Gore, Flagstaff, AZ) in sequence to preserve IIA flow (Figure 5). The first aortic stent graft is deployed, followed by a short 20-mm iliac limb extension. A second 23-mm Gore Excluder aortic stent graft is deployed into the 20-mm iliac limb. Using the brachial approach, the shorter docking limb of the second bifurcated device is bridged into the IIA using Excluder iliac limb extension or Viabahn stent grafts (WL Gore, Flagstaff AZ). A limitation of the technique is the added cost and need for longer lengths between the renal arteries and the aortic and iliac bifurcations.

caption.p: Double bifurcated or trifurcated stent graft technique using Gore Excluder stent grafts (WL Gore, Flagstaff, AZ)

sec.title: Iliac Branch Devices
sec.p: IBDs allow repair of aortoiliac aneurysms with a designed stent graft configuration planned to provide optimal seal and flow dynamics into the internal and external iliac arteries. Clinical experience is limited to 3 designs by Cook Medical Inc.31 A new design by WL Gore is undergoing clinical testing in the United States. Current designs include a bifurcated iliac side (ZBIS) branch device, also known as straight side-arm (S-IBD) IBD, the helical branch (H-IBD), and the bifurcated-bifurcated IBD (BB-IBD). The S-IBD has a relatively short overlapping zone and is intended for use with a balloon-expandable stent graft. A modification of the S-IBD using a flexible longer straight arm comparable to a nonwrapped H-IBD has also been applied clinically using a self-expandable stent graft. The H-IBD design is intended for use with a self-expandable stent graft by providing a longer overlapping zone. Both devices maintain the modular concept and are joined to a conventional Zenith bifurcated stent graft (Cook Medical, Bloomington, IN) by an extension limb component (Figure 6). The S- and H-IBD utilize the same 20Fr delivery system that includes a preloaded catheter through the branch and out of the proximal aspect of the device. The preloaded catheter allows the introduction of a wire, which is snared from an alternative site (usually the contralateral groin but also the brachial approach), and provides ready access through the branch with a sheath.

caption.p: Technique of total endovascular repair using a straight-arm iliac branch device (S-IBD, A). A guidewire is advanced into the preloaded catheter and snared via the contralateral femoral approach (B), allowing advancement of a 12Fr modified Ansel sheath (Cook Medical Inc, Bloomington, IN). Once access is established into the internal iliac artery, a self-expandable stent graft is positioned (C) and deployed (D). The repair is completed by placement of a bifurcated aortic stent graft via the contralateral side (E)

sec.p: The third and latest development is the bifurcated-bifurcated IBD or BB-IBD. This device involves a combination of the H-IBD with the distal bifurcated component of a fenestrated device. The addition of the helical side-arm to the ipsilateral (long) limb of a bifurcated aortic device makes conceptual sense because it eliminates 2 modular joints from an IBD repair but relegates access into the internal iliac branch to the brachial/axillary circulation. This limitation is overcome by the development of a self-sealing fenestration immediately cranial to the ostium of the helical branch origin on the medial wall of the iliac limb. The self-sealing fenestration is used in conjunction with a preloaded wire, which is snared in a manner identical to that with standard IBD devices. Mating of the helical limb is completed as above, and when the preloaded wire is removed, the sealing segment (a covered Z-stent) resides over the fenestration, functionally excluding the aneurysm.

sec.title: Anatomical Considerations
sec.p: Most anatomical factors have not been validated by clinical studies. Iliac tortuosity, calcifications, or stenosis affect the ability to introduce large-diameter sheaths and may predispose stent grafts to kinks or occlusion. Other characteristics of the distal IIA, such as aneurysmal involvement with inadequate distal landing zone or poor run-off because of distal branch vessel disease, represent limitations to any technique of pelvic revascularization, open or endovascular, including sandwich stent grafts.

In most reports, IBDs are indicated in patients with common iliac aneurysms greater than 20 to 24 mm. Distal fixation in the external iliac artery requires a minimum length of 20 mm and a “normal diameter” of 8 to 12 mm. For the H-IBD and S-IBD, the CIA should have a minimum length of 50 mm, or else, the IBD device will extend high up into the abdominal aorta. It is possible to complete the repair in patients with shorter common iliac arteries utilizing brachial access. The presence of IIA stenosis is not a contraindication but may increase technical difficulty. The IIA should have a nonaneurysmal segment (fixation site) of >10 mm length and inner-wall diameter of 6 to 10 mm. However, the latter can be overcome with the use of smaller diameter mating stent grafts.

sec.title: Technique
sec.p: The procedure is performed using the bilateral femoral approach. The main aortic device is usually introduced via the side opposite to the IBD. The target IIA should be imaged prior to deploying an IBD above the vessel. Following insertion of the IBD over a stiff wire, it is oriented such that the 3 markers immediately distal to the distal branch ostium align with the internal iliac ostium clock position on an axial direction. This facilitates snaring of the preloaded wire. Contralateral femoral access is established using a 12Fr modified Ansel sheath (Cook Inc, Bloomington, IN), which is placed at the origin of the CIA. The preloaded wire within the IBD is exchanged for a long glidewire, and the wire is snared and withdrawn through the contralateral groin. The H-IBD or S-IBD is advanced to the desired location with the side arm immediately above the IIA origin, and the sheath is withdrawn to expose the side branch. The 12Fr sheath is then advanced from the contralateral side up and over the aortic bifurcation into the side arm using the preloaded wire. A second puncture is then made in the valve of the 12F sheath, and a 5F sheath is placed, through which a steerable guidewire-catheter combination (Kumpe catheter, Cook Medical, Bloomington, IN) is advanced alongside the through-and-through wire within the 12F sheath. The “buddy” catheter and wire are used to cannulate the IIA and preferably advanced into the posterior (gluteal) branch of the target vessel. A stiff wire (Rosen or Amplatz, Cook Medical, Bloomington, IN) is then placed through the catheter and the catheter removed. The IIA is imaged in a manner that will demonstrate the branch terminus as well as the target sealing zone. An appropriate length mating stent graft is selected. In general, self-expandable stent grafts are used for H-IBDs (Fluency stent graft, Bard Peripheral Vascular Inc, Tempe, AZ). For S-IBDs, a balloon-expandable stent graft (iCAST, Atrium Medical, Hudson, NH; or Jomed, Abbott Labs, Red Oaks, CA) is used, but several prefer to use self-expandable stent grafts despite the shorter overlapping zone. Prior to deployment of the mating stent graft, the through-and-through wire is removed. Once the IBD and mating stent graft are fully deployed, the remainder of the branch is deployed by sheath withdrawal; the trigger wires are then deployed, leaving the internal iliac wire over which the mating stent graft was deployed in place, with an 8-mm balloon transcending the internal iliac and external iliac junction. The 8-mm balloon is then inflated, protecting the branch, and the delivery system is removed. A 12-mm balloon can then be inflated at the junction of the 2 iliac arteries in a kissing balloon fashion to ensure patency of the internal and external iliac arteries. The repair is then imaged by injecting through the 12F sheath. The remainder of the repair is carried out using a standard bifurcated modular component, which is introduced contralaterally. The IBD is mated to the remainder of the Zenith stent graft (Cook Medical Inc, Bloomington, IN) with a short iliac extension.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: More than 4000 IBDs have been implanted worldwide (Cook Medical, personal communication). Results of iliac branch stent grafts have been encouraging, with technical success rates of greater than 95% in most reports.7,32-37 The first reported series by Greenberg et al32 in 2006 included 21 patients with 3 technical failures (14%), all caused by inability to visualize the origin of the IIA as a result of significant stenosis. Since its initial conception, results of IBD have improved with newer generation devices. Ziegler et al38 analyzed 46 patients treated with S-IBDs, but the first 26 patients were treated using an early generation unibody configuration, and only the last 20 utilized the S-IBD system. Technical success improved from 58% with the early generation device to 85% with the current S-IBD. There were no perioperative deaths, and of the 35 IBDs successfully implanted, none developed endoleaks, component separations, or migration. There were 4 branch occlusions after a mean follow-up of 26 months. Other groups have reported excellent results with the newer generation S-IBD, with technical success rates of 91% to 100% and primary patency rates of 74% to 100% from 6 to 20 months of follow-up.4,34-36

The anatomical challenges frequently imposed by the tortuous anatomy of the iliac arteries, particularly in the setting of large aneurysms, has led to the development of the helical design by Greenberg and the group at the Cleveland Clinic.32,39 The helical branch provides a longer overlapping zone (>20 mm) between the common iliac device and the mating self-expandable stent graft. In addition, by using a self-expandable stent instead of the balloon-expandable stent, the mating stent graft adapts better to the iliac tortuosity and to the acute angle at the IIA origin, which potentially reduce kinks and late stent graft occlusion. The results of a multicenter prospective study in 52 patients treated with 53 helical branched stent grafts included a technical success rate of 94%, with no endoleaks or component separations.39 There were 6 branch occlusions, all within the first month. It is important to note that whereas none of the patients with patent branches developed claudication, all those who developed branch occlusion could pinpoint the date of thrombosis based on the development of claudication.

Verzini et al4 from Perugia, Italy, reported the only comparative analysis of IBDs versus hypogastric exclusion in 74 patients. In this study, there were no differences in procedure time, contrast use, and technical success and no early deaths. However, there was a trend toward more endoleaks (19% vs 4%) and pelvic ischemic symptoms (22% vs 4%) among patients treated with coil embolization when compared with those treated with IBDs. Recently, the authors reported the 5-year results in 100 consecutive patients, with 91.4% patency in 1 and 5 years and an intervention-free rate in 5 years of 81.4%.40

Karthikesalingam et al41 reported a systematic analysis of 9 studies that included 196 patients treated with IBDs. The anatomical suitability for IBD was not detailed in most studies, but Tielliu et al35 described that only 27 (52%) of their 52 potential candidates for IBD met all the following anatomical criteria: common iliac diameter >18 mm and absence of excessive iliac tortuosity, internal iliac aneurysm, or severe stenosis. The median operative time ranged from 101 to 290 minutes, and the contrast load was 58 to 208 mL. Technical success ranged from 85% to 100%. There were no aneurysm-related deaths. Only 1 patient with patent IBD complained of buttock claudication. However, late thrombosis of the IBD occurred in 24 patients (12%) and resulted in buttock claudication in 12 (50%). Endoleak rates were exceedingly low, with only 1 type-I (0.5%) and 2 type-III endoleaks (1%). Type-II endoleaks were treated conservatively and were not associated with sac expansion. Reinterventions were required in 12 patients (6%), including in 5 with occlusion stent graft limbs to the external iliac artery.

In the absence of commercially available IBDs, the technique of modification of the Cook Zenith (Cook Medical, Bloomington, IN) iliac extension limb was described by Oderich and Ricotta.42 The procedure may be used selectively in high-risk patients with bilateral IIA aneurysms who do not have access to a manufactured IBD. The technique of device modification is reported elsewhere, and device implantation is nearly identical to that already described for manufactured IBDs.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Endovascular treatment of aortoiliac aneurysms can be challenging, particularly in patients who are felt not to be ideally suited for any open surgical procedure. The option of unilateral or bilateral IIA embolization has a predictable risk of complication, most notably buttock claudication and erectile dysfunction; but also rarely, serious complications occur, such as ischemic colitis, gluteal muscle necrosis, and spinal cord injury. IBDs represent a significant improvement in the treatment of aortoiliac aneurysms by allowing preservation of pelvic flow with a totally endovascular technique. However, the widespread use of IBDs is fraught with challenges, including regulatory approval, physician training, and an evaluation of the late results of IBDs, including device integrity, reinterventions, and occlusion rates.
